article.title: The genealogical tree of ethanol: gas-phase formation of glycolaldehyde, acetic acid and formic acid

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main focus of this scientific article?
choices: The role of grain-surface chemistry in the formation of iCOMs.
A proposed gas-phase formation route for glycolaldehyde and its connection to other iCOMs.
The abundance of ethanol in hot corinos and shock sites.
The challenges of observing formic acid in interstellar environments.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the proposed initiating step in the new gas-phase reaction scheme for glycolaldehyde formation?
choices: Reaction of ethanol with either atomic chlorine or hydroxyl radicals.
UV or particle irradiation of simple molecules on grain surfaces.
Recombination of radicals trapped in amorphous water ice.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the MAIN reason given in the article for the overprediction of acetic acid and formic acid abundances by the new model?
choices: The assumed abundance of injected ethanol is too high.
The rate coefficients for the new reactions are uncertain at low temperatures.
Important destruction routes involving radicals might be missing in the reaction network.
The model does not accurately account for the physical conditions in hot corinos.

multiple_choice_question.text: Based on Figure 4, what trend is observed regarding the predicted abundance of glycolaldehyde?
choices: It is independent of the ethanol abundance.
It decreases with increasing ethanol abundance.
It increases with increasing ethanol abundance.
It peaks at a specific ethanol abundance and then decreases.
